command: [Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [Net.SecurityProtocolType]::Tls12; $ErrorActionPreference='Stop'; $domain='example.com'; $out='C:\ProgramData\recon\securitytrails_example.com.json'; New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path C:\ProgramData\recon | Out-Null; $log='C:\ProgramData\recon\recon.log'; try { $key=$env:SECURITYTRAILS_API_KEY; if([string]::IsNullOrWhiteSpace($key)){ throw 'SECURITYTRAILS_API_KEY not set'; } $headers=@{ 'APIKEY'=$key; 'Accept'='application/json' }; $uri="https://api.securitytrails.com/v1/domain/$domain"; $resp=Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $uri -Headers $headers -Method Get -UseBasicParsing -TimeoutSec 30 -ErrorAction Stop; if(($resp.StatusCode -ge 200) -and ($resp.StatusCode -lt 300) -and ($resp.Headers['Content-Type'] -match 'application/json')){ ($resp.Content | ConvertFrom-Json) | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 6 | Set-Content -Path $out -Encoding UTF8 } else { Add-Content -Path $log -Value "$(Get-Date -Format o) SecurityTrails non-success or non-JSON for $domain. Status=$($resp.StatusCode)" } } catch { Add-Content -Path $log -Value "$(Get-Date -Format o) SecurityTrails error for $domain: $($_.Exception.Message)" }
explanation: Collects domain intelligence from SecurityTrails, a subscription-based closed-source dataset, using API authentication and structured JSON handling.
rationale_steps: Use API key via header to authenticate to SecurityTrails.
Request domain profile data over TLS.
Verify JSON response, then parse and persist to JSON.
Log operational errors to a central log.
